importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Retail coffee prices increased nearly 21% in August 2025 compared to the same period in 2024, indicating a sharp rise in consumer costs due to tariffs and supply issues.
Brazil was slapped with a 50% tariff in July 2025, which significantly increased import costs and contributed to higher coffee prices in the U.S.
A bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee products from tariffs, signaling potential legislative action to mitigate rising prices.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from mid-2025 to late 2025 highlights the impact of Trump-era tariffs on coffee pricing, with significant costs emerging in July and continuing into October.

keyTakeAways: The U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil supplying 30.7% of imports, Colombia 18.3%, and Vietnam 6.6%.

A 50% tariff on Brazilian coffee, a 20% tariff on Vietnamese coffee, and a 10% tariff on Colombian coffee have increased import costs and contributed to a 21% year-over-year rise in retail coffee prices.
Average restaurant coffee prices rose to $3.52 in August 2025, with a $4.21 average for hot coffee in Washington, DC and $5.35 for cold brew, both up from the previous year.
Small coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting have reported increased costs due to tariffs, leading to higher prices for consumers.
Owners report that bean costs have increased from $4 to $6 per pound and by up to 50 cents per 12-ounce bag, with uncertainty affecting business viability.
The 50% tariff on Brazil, exacerbated by a drought reducing supply, has had the most significant impact on roaster businesses.
Consumers may switch brands or seek deals, but coffee remains perceived as an affordable luxury and consumption habits are unlikely to change drastically.
A bipartisan bill, the 'No Coffee Tax Act', was introduced in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs, offering potential relief.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration imposed high tariffs on coffee imports, directly increasing costs for U.S. roasters and consumers.

namedEntities.name: Brazil
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brazil is the largest source of U.S. coffee imports (30.7%) and was hit with a 50% tariff, significantly increasing import costs and disrupting supply chains.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vietnam supplies 6.6% of U.S. coffee imports and faced a 20% tariff, contributing to increased bean costs and higher retail prices.

namedEntities.name: Colombia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Colombia supplies 18.3% of U.S. coffee imports and has a 10% tariff, adding to overall import costs and affecting roaster expenses.

namedEntities.name: Swing’s Coffee Roasters
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This Virginia and DC-based roaster has been directly affected by tariffs, with owner Mark Warmuth stating that costs and consumer prices have increased significantly.

namedEntities.name: Vigilante Coffee Company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This California and Maryland-based roaster reported bean prices rising from $4 to $6 per pound and has explored diversifying imports to manage costs.

namedEntities.name: Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This Maryland-based roaster avoids Brazilian coffee due to 50% tariffs and has observed increased costs in bean prices, affecting margins.

namedEntities.name: Qualia Coffee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This DC-based business sells at farmers’ markets and faces uncertainty due to fluctuating prices and tariff risks, impacting long-term planning.

namedEntities.name: Don Bacon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Republican representative from Nebraska who co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' to remove tariffs on coffee.

namedEntities.name: Ro Khanna
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democratic representative from California who co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Toast
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A restaurant management software provider that collected data showing a 21% year-over-year increase in coffee prices in August 2025.

namedEntities.name: National Coffee Association
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The organization states that the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, highlighting coffee's dependence on international supply chains.

namedEntities.name: UN Comtrade Database
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of data showing Brazil’s 30.7% share of U.S. coffee imports based on net weight.

namedEntities.name: Conference Board
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A nonprofit research group whose senior economist, Erin McLaughlin, provided economic analysis on consumer behavior amid rising coffee prices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration's imposition of high tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—has significantly increased the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% year-over-year rise in U.S. retail coffee prices. With Brazil being the largest supplier (30.7% of imports), the 50% tariff has had the most profound impact, especially amid a drought reducing supply. Multiple coffee roasters in the U.S., including Swing’s, Vigilante, and Celtic Cup, report higher bean and beverage costs, which are passed on to consumers. Despite economic pressure, consumers continue to view coffee as an affordable luxury, and small businesses face uncertainty in pricing and long-term viability. In response, a bipartisan group of legislators, including Reps. Don Bacon and Ro Khanna, introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' in September 2025 to exempt coffee from tariffs, aiming to stabilize prices and protect consumers and small roasters.
title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Brewing Trouble for Coffee Roasters
